instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2338: What is A2338? A2338 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2020 M1, Mid 2022 M2 with EMC 8162, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02020, 820-02773..
definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5.18v 1.38a no power
threads.message:
no sign of corrosion
unable to boot even dfu mode
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> 12.31v stable
sometimes it ables to turn 20v with 1.37amp freeze (very rare) 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> 12.02V
replaced 2 <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips and <CHIP>U5200</CHIP> nothing changes.
can you help me what to do next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5.18v 1.38a no power
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL>?
Check MASTER PMU LDO and BUCKS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5.18v 1.38a no power
threads.message:
found shorted on <SIGNAL>PPVDD_ECPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 0.020 ohms 
removed L82B1/B0 still shorted. 
i think cpu is fried.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5.18v 1.38a no power
threads.message: Any chance to compare the reading with working board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5.18v 1.38a no power
threads.message: yes i have working board to compare i believed the short circuit is coming from cpu.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5.18v 1.38a no power
threads.message:
If possible (and you have time), please upload a list with diode mode readings on all coils from the working board.
This can help other members in the future.
We have lack of information about these new M1 boards...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5.18v 1.38a no power
threads.message: okay will posted it soon. thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5.18v 1.38a no power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Jeffotskie26, post: 86006, member: 28596"]
found shorted on <SIGNAL>PPVDD_ECPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 0.020 ohms
removed L82B1/B0 still shorted.
i think cpu is fried.
[/QUOTE]
Not a short. What is resistance to ground on this line? 

_________________________________

1.38 amps is too high. Is the battery connected? If so disconnect it. Does the amperage remain high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5.18v 1.38a no power
threads.message:
Not really short, but very low resistance comparing with good board; "L82B0/B1    168    <SIGNAL>PPVDD_ECPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL>"
So there is a problem with that power line for sure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 5.18v 1.38a no power
threads.message:
Here is normal diode and resistance measurements from a known good board I recorded and posted on repair.wiki. Keep in mind silicon resistance changes with heat. The board must be cold at room temp to get accurate readings. Was the board hot by chance when you measured this? Anything above 100*C will result in vastly different readings compared to room temp. 



L8100 / L8101 / L8102 (<SIGNAL>PPVDD_PCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL>) - Normal diode mode to ground reading ~0.007 / ~45Ω

L82B0 / L82B1 (<SIGNAL>PPVDD_ECPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL>) - Normal diode mode to ground reading ~0.114 / 140Ω

L8270 / L8271 (<SIGNAL>PPVDD_CPU_SRAM_AWAKE</SIGNAL>) - Normal diode mode to ground reading ~ 0.116 / 450Ω

L8120 / L8121 (<SIGNAL>PPVDD_SOC_S1</SIGNAL>) - Normal diode mode to ground reading ~ 0.012 / 110Ω

L8110 / L8111 / L8112 (<SIGNAL>PPVDD_GPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL>) - Normal diode mode to ground reading ~ 0.010 / 35Ω

L8280 / L8281 (<SIGNAL>PPVDD_DISP_S1</SIGNAL>) - Normal diode mode to ground reading ~ 0.055 / 233Ω

L8290 (<SIGNAL>PPVDD_DCS_S1</SIGNAL>) - Normal diode mode to ground reading ~ 0.176 / 310Ω

L84E0 - (<SIGNAL>PP1V4_LDO_PREREG</SIGNAL>) - Normal diode mode to ground reading ~ 0.285 / >30kΩ
